column1: #Text=Cromford is a village of approximately 1500 inhabitants in Derbyshire , in the wooded valley of the river Derwent , 17 miles north of Derby .

#Text=The area from Masson Mill in Cromford to the Silk Mill in Derby was declared a UNESCO Derwent Valley Mills World Heritage Site in recognition of the significant sites in the valley that influenced the development of the Industrial Revolution .

#Text=By rail from Derby on the Derwent Valley Line , operated by East Midlands Trains ; railway station is a short distance outside the village , a level walk of approx 3/4-mile ( allow at least 15 minutes ) .
#Text=On the main A6 Derby to Manchester trunk road .
#Text=Nearest motorway is M1 : J26 if travelling from the south or J28 if travelling from the north .
#Text=National Express service 440 daily from/to Manchester/ London via Matlock .
#Text=TransPeak long-distance bus line from Derby to Manchester and return stops in the village ; daytime services approx every hour .
#Text=TransPeak is also good for accessing the Peak District heartland , stopping at Bakewell and Buxton and various scenic locations .
#Text=Also served by Trent Barton 6.1 Derby-Bakewell service via Belper , Wirksworth and Matlock .
#Text=The first water-powered cotton spinning mill developed by Richard Arkwright in 1771 .
#Text=Buildings are being restored , an informative tour available but little machinery to see .
#Text=Sir Richard Arkwright 's water-powered cotton spinning mill built in 1783 .
#Text=Canal warehouse buildings and the northern terminus of the Cromford Canal , built in 1794 .
#Text=Walk or cycle the path of the old The Cromford and High Peak Railway which was opened in 1831 .
#Text=Trail starts at High Peak Junction , just south of the village .

#Text=Small country house-style hotel in quiet setting , own grounds and rural views .
#Text=Convenient for industrial heritage Arkwright 's Cromford Mill and historic village of Cromford .
